column2: In the midst of the coronavirus pandemic, the senior monks of Abhayagiri Monastery offered a nine-day hybrid retreat to celebrate its 25th anniversary. Only two Q&A sessions and a talk by Ajahn Pasanno are currently included in the Archive.

column6: Session title

Text
In 1995, the Saṅgha in England finally gives permission for a more permanent monastic residence in California. Master Hua offers Ajahn Sumedho 125 acres in Redwood Valley the next day.
Ajahn Pasanno offers to help Ajahn Amaro with the California monastery project.
The property next door: "You can either buy it or forget it."
The day before Abhayagiri opened; Ajahn Pasanno moves to Abhayagiri.
Abhayagiri's first kutis.
Generous contributions in the early days of Abhayagiri.
Abhayagiri: a place of safety.
The original Abhayagiri Monastery.
[The Path to Freedom (Vimuttimagga)](https://buddhistuniversity.net/content/monographs/vimuttimagga_nyanatusita), translated by Bhikkhu Ñāṇatusita
Our warm relationship with the City of Ten Thousand Buddhas.
Ajahn Sumedho is invited to teach from Master Hua's Dhamma seat.
The first days of Wat Pah Nanachat.
Ajahn Liem declares that the Abhayagiri's Reception Hall will last at least 150 years.
Ajahn Sumedho was a catalyst for Abhayagiri to happen.
You should appreciate all that Ajahn Sumedho has done. He's been the tank that has prepared the way for all the rest of you.|Ajahn Chah
Ajahn Sumedho is the most senior American bhikkhu in the world.
These days Ajahn Sumedho is on fire teaching Dhamma.
He's not talking a lot about the details. He's talking about the essence. It's very beautiful.
As of mid-2024, Ajahn Sumedho continues to give weekly Dhamma talks available on [Amaravati's YouTube channel](https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL--llepYBCu4lh112KIeRZ75keS_283ox).
Ajahn Chah is the inspiration for all of us.
If buffaloes can learn, surely these farangs [foreigners] can learn.|Ajahn Chah
Anagārika Lief requests to become a novice.
How do I put the Four Noble Truths into practice in daily life?
Can you talk more about the shift from feeling unsafe to feeling safe?
Being alive has many inherent risks.
In living with others, we tend to stick with our perceptions, causing potential conflict with them. How can we accept others as they are and be able to live with others harmoniously?
How should a person cope with loneliness without having to rely on other things/people/contact?
What is the attitude to have towards others who are not on the path but are close family members?
How can you hold appreciation and gratitude and not lose an awareness of dukkha and understanding of dukkha?

Returning to the knowing' was described as aware, awake, and bright. I understand aware and awake. Is the brightness something that comes up naturally because of lack of kilesas or something that the mind is lifted to?
In the 'Verses of Sharing and Aspiration' (Chanting Book p. 33), what is the threefold bliss?
Could you suggest some inquiry questions to contemplate and investigate the wisdom practice of equanimity?
Chanting Book p. 55.
For the next 25 years, what will be the leading light for the direction of Abhayagiri? Is there any collective vision?
What could I to to help myself fear death less?
The idea that Ajahn Pasanno would leave Wat Pah Nanachat never occured to us.
Ajahn Pasanno advices Ajahn Sudanto to stay in Thailand for his navaka training.
I wanted to contribute to establishing something in America out of enormous gratitude for what was offered in Thailand to me and my peers.
Abhayagiri looked like a Buddhist trailer park.
The frequency of teachings and level of Dhamma practice is uncommon even among Thai Ajahn Chah monasteries.
Ajahn Pasanno invited Ajahn Sudanto to return to Abhayagiri in 2002, where he spends most of the next 12 years.
Twenty-five years on, we're still building the monastery. It's a bit like a cathedral project.
Part of the original vision [for Abhayagiri] was to establish a place for Saṅgha in America.
The time I spent here and gave to this project [Abhayagiri] is a substantial blessing in my life.
My first encounter with the Thai Forest Tradition.
I'm not going all the way to England to live with some guy from Seattle to practice Thai Buddhism.
"It would be a lot nicer in a forest in America."
of early Abhayagiri monks.
Abhayagiri is off to a good start.
If you really want to pay homage to me, do the practice.|The Buddha
DN 16.5: Mahāparinibbāna Sutta.
Ajahn Sumedho's early visits to California.
Affinities between the communities of Ajahn Sumedho and Master Hsuan Hua.
Master Hua invites Ajahn Sumedho to help conduct an ordination ceremony at the City of Ten Thousand Buddhas.
Ajahn Sumedho invites Master Hua to the English monasteries.
The formation of Saṅghapāla Foundation in December 1988.
Ajahn Sumedho visits the Bay Area in 1990 and chooses Ajahn Amaro to lead the California project.
Ajahn Amaro leads a series of temporary California vihāras.
In May 1994, the English Saṅgha Trust gives Ajahn Amaro permission to start looking for property in California. Master Hua offers 125 acres of forest in Mendocino County the next day.
Ajahn Amaro visits the Abhayagiri property for the first time.
Buying the property next to the land Master Hua donated.
Moving onto the Abhayagiri land.
Ajahn Pasanno's involvement in the Abhayagiri project.
Serendipitous generosity in the early days of Abhayagiri.
Ajahn, maybe if you just taught Theravāda Buddhism, that would be great.|A Saṅghapāla board member to Ajahn Amaro
It wasn't sensible to try to be all things to all people.
Abhayagiri ethos:|We all live in the forest. Everyone's in a kuti.|
Mindfulness of the body is an absolute necessity.
++Quote:++ "We're not about doing retreats. We're a community." — {teachers} speaking about Abhayagiri.
Shedding, impermanence, and not-self: ++Reflections++ on moving to Amaravati by {teachers}.
Die before you die.|Ajahn Chah
The tone and flavor of Dhamma is bittersweet.
Do you miss Abhayagiri?
Snp 5.11: The island you cannot go beyond.
How do you avoid falling in the trap of caring about something/someone too much and becoming attached to that something/someone?
How do we overcome regret and remorse associated with not being able to do good or meet our loved ones at the time of passing away?

I struggle to find meaning in life....I struggle to find what to do during my days and what to do in the future in terms of career or lifestyle....What would be your advice for someone who feels lost as to what to do next in his/her life?

I struggle with restlessness. I always want to be doing something, and I often end up doing several things at the same time so it's draining and not enjoyable. It's very difficult to stop, and when I stop, I don't know what to do, so I might grab my iPhone, clean stuff....Could you talk about restlessness and how to do nothing if that's actually possible?
Why do we forget past lives?

A question about Dogenji's teaching: 'To study the Buddha Way is to study the self. To study the self is to forget the self. To forget the self is to be actualized by myriad things. When actualized by myriad things your body and mind as well as the bodies and minds of others drop away. No trace of enlightenment remains, and this no trace continues endlessly.' Can you reflect on this teaching from the Theravāda Thai Forest Teachings?
Everything is teaching us. Everything is a manifestation of Dhamma and truth.|Ajahn Chah

I'm lucky not to have any obligations such as taking care of a family, making money, working, etc., but I don't know what to do with my life....Always wondering what to do with my life is a bit tough. How would you suggest I approach the situation?...How do you figure out what to do with your life when you have too much freedom?
See also [Question 3](excerpt:Anniversary2021_S9_F3) in this same session.
In our worldly life we always have expectations on things that we do. What would be the best way for us to change this habit and do everything without expectations?
Does Luang Por Pasanno know what happened to Ajahn Visuddhi or Christine Lee?
What can I do to stop judging?

Thank you for your talk today. You mentioned giving the opportunity for everyone to practice and train. However, there seem to be no Ajahn Chah monasteries in the US and Canada where women can ordain and train. Would Abhayagiri be open to having a female monastic community at some point in the future?

I remember reading in one of Ajahn Chah's books about comparing our feelings to a snake with sadness and unhappiness at its head and happiness as its tail and how we should not touch any part of its body....How can we just watch [feelings] come in and out of our mind without interacting with it or getting influenced by it?
"The Middle Way Within," Collected Teachings p. 2.
What is the meaning of the inscription on the Buddha statue behind you?
A sense of causeless joy permeates awareness, yet there remains a sense of me that experiences. How to dissolve that?
Why do the monks keep their eyes closed during meditation?
How do you recognize when craving has arisen?
When practicing letting go, is there any particular order to do so? For example, if I am attached to career, friends, and family (in order of increasing attachment), which shall I let go of first?
If everything in life is great, and I am enjoying my life, why practice? What could get better?

How do you feel the holes? How do you feel good without the need for anything external/addictions, in other words, coping mechanisms. How do you deal with and move past what lies underneath these mechanisms?
Should we consider the brahmavihāras a form of emotion or are they kinds of knowledge or understanding?
Can you please talk more about the three happinesses and what we should be careful about?
Verses of Sharing and Aspiration, Chanting Book p. 33.
I have loaned something to my brother, and he just won't give it back to me no matter how many times I ask him. How would you approach this situation?
Have you ever suffered from some sort of addiction and how did you recover from it? What would be your advice for someone suffering from an addiction?
Could you please explain how one practices applied and sustained thought in breath meditation?
Could you please explain why the ajahn holds a fan in front of himself during the taking of refuges?
